$AMD is now the 24th largest public company in the world.

The PEG ratio compares a company‚Äôs P/E multiple to its expected earnings CAGR, typically over the next 3 years so it adjusts valuation for how fast the business is actually growing.  

$GOOGL ratio looks elevated at ~27x forward earnings mainly because near-term growth is modeled at only ~6% next year which then pulls down the 3-year CAGR.

MY 5 BIGGEST TAKEAWAYS FROM $AMD ANALYST DAY 

1. The pivot is official that AMD it‚Äôs building a platform with a goal is to sell full AI infrastructure: silicon, interconnect, software & racks that hyperscalers can deploy at scale. It‚Äôs chasing $NVDA vertical model but through an open ecosystem.

2. Data center is the company with Lisa guiding for ~35% CAGR, 57% gross margins & >$20 EPS by 2030. That requires DC biz to grow from ~$16B today to near $100B within five years which is a 6x run that only works if MI450 + Helios hit ramp targets & hyperscaler orders stack fast.

3. GPU is the upside but ROCm is the gatekeeper. The MI450 & yearly GPU cadence will define whether AMD becomes a real platform or stays a second source. Success hinges on ROCm feeling as stable and integrated as CUDA but partnerships with $META, $ORCL & OpenAI are the first real signs of ecosystem lift.

4. CPUs fund the fight with the server share near 40% gives AMD the profit engine it needs. As AI inference workloads push compute back toward CPUs, crossing 50% share does actually look realistic & that stable cash flow supports GPU & software expansion without breaking margins.

5. Michael Burry is wrong.

$EOSE signed a joint development deal with Bimergen Energy to deploy its zinc-based long-duration battery systems across the U.S.

They‚Äôre starting with 1 GWh of late-stage ERCOT projects as both teams align on design, procurement & financing to scale grid storage.

Daily Market Brief:
northmantrader.com/2025/11/1‚Ä¶

Restoring the dream of American homeownership is going to require lower prices.

Are the 86M current homeowners, and the shareholders of Pulte homes, ok with this?

The 45M renters, comprising 100M people are begging for it.

9/10 people have never seen these numbers and think the last 20-30 years is just how housing markets work
but every long run index shows similar stability 
heres one that goes back 400 years

Add-on

Housing is so expensive (see chart above) that it now consumes almost half of income. 

(High prices, rather than mortgage rates, insurance, or upkeep, are the primary driver of this. Property taxes are a function of high prices.)

What is housing?

Something that Gov't policy should make affordable? The 45M renters (~100M people) want this.

A savings vehicle that funds retirement and economies? 85M homeowners (~180M people) want this.
--
It cannot be both, as these are competing goals.

When prices go up, Renters are priced out of the market, making homes unaffordable for them. This is the case today.

When prices go down, homeowners worry that their retirement and lifestyle are at risk. Financial institutions worry losses will become a problem (see 2008).
--
This is why I quip that housing is perpetually in crisis. One of these two groups (renters or homeowners) is ALWAYS unhappy. See the chart

To repeat the question at the top, what do we want from housing? Something everyone should have (cheap) or a way to retire (expensive).

The chart above is over 2 years old. And the Atlanta Fed has a better county-by-county metric (white is counties too small).

Here is the latest map.

Very little of the country is still blue. None of them is a larger urban area.

üì∫ $TSLA & $NVDA: STUCK IN CONSOLIDATION MODE

üì∫ MONEY FLOWS BACK TO BIG TECH: HOW I‚ÄôM PLAYING IT
